title: What is the number of atoms in 2.3 kg of Na? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can work this out for any pure element, gas or liquid from the definition of the Avogadro Number. That number is 6.022 x 10^23 and is the number of atoms (in an elemental form) or molecules (pure chemical compounds) in 1 gram-mole of a substance - ie, the atomic or molecular weight expressed in grams. In the case of 2.3 kg of Na the number of moles is 2300/22.99 from which you can calculate the number of atoms in the 2.3 kg of the metal.

Well if you try the question it is actually quite easy. The molar mass of Na is 23g/mol This means 23g Na is 1mol of Na.Thus 2300g of Na is= (1/23)×2300=100mols.Here 2.3kg =2300g.Now 1mol Na has 6.022×10^23 atoms.So 100 mol Na has 6.022×10^25 atoms and that's the answer. :-)

Molar Mass of Na is 22.98g So, 6.022 * 10^(23) atoms are present in 22.98g. So , 1 g corresponds to 6.022 *10^23/ 22.98 = 2.62* 10^ 22 atoms So, 2.3 kg corresponds to 2.62*10^22* 2300 = 6026*10^22 atoms Hence, there are 6026 *10^22 sodium atoms in 2.3 kg of Na

One mole atoms of Na weigh 23 grams.(one mole means Avogadro's no. of atoms which has a value of 6.022*10²³. 2.3 Kg means 2300 grams of Na. Since 23 grams consist of one mole atoms, 2300 grams will consist of 100 moles( unitary method). Therefore, the atoms of Na in 2.3 kg of it would be 100 moles, that is, 6.022*10^25

Atomic mass of Na = 23 Number of moles = given mass / atomic mass n = 2.3 × 1000/23 = 100 mol No. of atoms (x) = Number of moles × Avogadro's number = n × N So, x= 100 × 6.022 × 10²³ =6.022 × 10 ^25 atoms

It is 6.22×10^19 (say M) Molecular mass of Na is 23g=1 mol Now, 1 mol of any substance contains 6.22×10^22 (N=Avogadro no.) molecules. So, 2.3kg Na = 2300g Na Now, 23g Na = N molecules Therefore, 2300g Na = M molecules
